title-group.article-title: Simulation and implementation of a new crankshaft and connecting rod-type radial-plunger low-speed-high-torque hydraulic motor with digital distributor

abstract.p: A new type of radial-plunger low-speed-high-torque (LSHT) hydraulic motor with digital distributor, which has ten high-speed solenoid on/off valves (HSVs) is proposed. It is a reconstructed hydraulic motor of the traditional one (Staffa motor). Compared with the traditional LSHT hydraulic motor with shaft or plane distribution mechanism, the operating principle of the new hydraulic motor is introduced and the distribution tables for both rotary directions are given at first. Then, the mathematical model of the new hydraulic motor is established by analysing piston dynamics for every section of angle. After that, the related simulations are made and the results show that the new hydraulic motor can work well with the digital distributor. The rotary speed of the new hydraulic motor can be easily changed by altering the duty cycle of the control signal which applies to the HSVs. To validate the feasibility of the proposed new hydraulic motor, the model machine is developed and the experiments are carried out. The experimental results demonstrate that the new hydraulic motor can rotate continuously with the digital distributor. In addition to that, the rotary speed and direction can also be easily changed by applying the proper control signal to the HSVs.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: As hydraulic actuator, the crankshaft and connecting rod-type radial-plunger low-speed-high-torque (LSHT) hydraulic motor has a wide range of applications, including mining machine, building machine and injection moulding machine, because it can be connected directly to the load. For these hydraulic motors, a key component is the distribution mechanism by which the pressurized oil is distributed to corresponding working cylinders. Although the shaft distribution and the plane distribution mechanisms (traditional distribution mechanisms) are commonly used, these two types of distribution mechanisms have lots of disadvantages such as complex structure, high machining cost and unease of speed adjusting.

During the past decades, many researchers worked hard to improve the performance of the LSHT hydraulic motor with traditional distribution mechanisms. Tan [1, 2] developed the mathematical model of the shaft distribution mechanism and found that the leakage ripple with the rotation of hydraulic motor. Li [3, 4] did a lot of work about the plane distribution mechanism, including the theory and validation through experiments. For example, he presented a new design of plane distribution pair which could balance the titling moment of the distributor completely. Other researchers concentrated on the slipper pairs in the LSHT hydraulic motor [5]. They put forward pressure-flow analytical formulas of lubrication film of slipper pair and studied the dynamic process of lubrication film formation through squeezing. A high pressurized design method of slipper pairs was proposed compared with the traditional hydro-static bearing structure. They also carried out the experiments to prove the effectiveness of the new design method. However, the earlier researches are concentrated on how to improve the performance of distribution mechanism, but not to design a new one. They cannot completely overcome the disadvantages of the mechanism mentioned above. In order tochange the thing thoroughly, a new distribution mechanism should be found.

As the wide applications of computer technology, real time computer control manner for electro-hydraulic control system has become an important trend for hydraulic technology development. The digital valves can connect with the computers directly without any D/A transfer unit. Compared with servovalves and proportional valves, digital valves have advantages of compact design, low cost, anti-contamination,high repeat precision, and low power loss [6]. For example, the emergence of high-speed solenoid on/off valve (HSV) and its application in common-rail electronically controlled diesel fuel injection system is potentially interesting [7–9]. The function of HSVs employed in the diesel fuel injection system is to inject the high-pressure diesel fuel into the corresponding working cylinder. The principle can be applied to the radial-plunger LSHT hydraulic motor as well. Another example that combines hydraulic and modern computer technology is the digital-displacement pump-motor. This is a hybrid device, which combines reciprocating hydraulics with micro-processor control, creating a highly integrated machine capable of producing variable flow and power [10]. Ehsan et al. [11] then apply it as hydraulic drives in the year 2000. The patent (EP 0494236B1) related to a fluid-driven or fluid-driving machine having a plurality of working chambers of cyclically changing volume and valve means to control the connection of each chamber sequentially to low and high-pressure manifolds [12]. The authors of the patent anticipated that using of electromagnetic poppet valves open the possibility for full electronic control with all the sophistication and precision. Thenew hydraulic motor mentioned in this article has two main differences from the machine in the patent. First, the hydraulic motor here employs the HSVs instead of the electromagnetic poppet valves. The distribution task of the hydraulic motor can be fulfilled using the HSVs, and its rotation speed is also easily changed by altering the duty cycle of the pulse width modulation (PWM) signals applied to the HSVs.Second, the new hydraulic motor is a kind of radial-plunger motor and the machine mentioned in the patent is a kind of axial-plunger one.

In this article, a new type of LSHT hydraulic motor with digital distributor is proposed. The plane distribution mechanism is removed from the body of LSHThydraulic motor and instead by a distribution block with ten HSVs. The operating principle is introduced first. It is followed by analysing the mathematical model of the new hydraulic motor. Then, the simulation is made based on the model. In order to testify the new hydraulic motor, the experimental research is conducted and the results convince that the reconstructed hydraulic motor can work well with the new digital distribution mechanism.

sec.title: 2 OPERATING PRINCIPLE
sec.p: In order to have a better understanding of the operating principle for the new type LSHT hydraulic motor, it is necessary to introduce the principle of the hydraulic motor with traditional distribution mechanism.

sec.title: 2.1 Principle of hydraulic motor with shaft distribution mechanism
sec.p:
The commonly used LSHT hydraulic motor is the crankshaft and connecting rod-type radial-plunger motor with shaft distribution or plane distribution mechanism. Figure 1 shows the operating principle of shaft distribution hydraulic motor which has five cylinder blocks arranged radially against the spherical surface of case (1) with an equal distance apart, forming a star-shaped cylinder block. The piston (2) is set in the cylinder block and connected with connecting rod (3) through spherical hinges. The geometrical centre of the crankshaft is o1 and has an offset e with respect to the rotation centre o. Distribution shaft (5) and crankshaft (4) joint together through a cross-key and rotates with the crankshaft. As is shown in Fig. 1, cylinders (1), (2), and (3) connect with high-pressure oil and the other ones connect with the outlet port. The pressurized oil produces the push force in each cylinder and sequentially generates a tangential forceN which forms a torque against the rotation centre and drives the crankshaft to rotate. With the rotation of crankshaft, the number of cylinders which are connected to inlet port changes between 2 and 3, supplying a continuous torque. Therefore, the crankshaft rotates continuously. The hydraulic motor with plane distribution mechanism has the same operating principle. Fig. 1
Operating principle of crank and connecting rod-type radial-plunger hydraulic motor: 1, case; 2, piston; 3, connecting rod; 4, crankshaft; 5, distribution shaft

sec.title: 2.2 Schematic of LSHT hydraulic motor with digital distributor
sec.p:
From the analysis of LSHT hydraulic motor with shaftdistribution mechanism, one can infer that if the pressurized oil is distributed into the working cylinders correctly according to the angle of crankshaft, the hydraulic motor will rotate continuously. Inspired by the technology used in common-rail electronically controlled diesel fuel injection system, the HSVs can be employed to realize the distribution task of LSHT hydraulic motor [13, 14]. The idea is interpreted in Fig. 2. Fig. 2
Operating principle of new type LSHT hydraulic motor: 1–10, HSVs; 11, oil source; 12, ECU; 13, control line

As can be seen from Fig. 2, there are three parts including ten HSVs, an absolute rotary encoder (10 bit resolution) and the Electrical Control Unit (ECU) compared to the traditional LSHT hydraulic motor. The absolute rotary encoder rotates with the hydraulic motor because it is connected to the crankshaft of hydraulic motor by coupling. The signal of angle (between 0° and 360°) is sent to the ECU which decides the on/off states of ten HSVs.

Suppose the angle of crankshaft is 0° when the piston is at the top of cylinder 1. From Fig. 2, one knows that the hydraulic motor will rotate counter clockwise (CCW) if the pressurized oil is distributed into the cylinders (1), (2), and (3). When the angle is 36°, the working cylinders change to (1) and (2) and in turn change to (5), (1), and (1). As a result, the distribution table for CCW rotation is obtained and shown in Table 1. sec.title: 3 MATHEMATICAL MODEL
sec.p: The mathematical model of traditional LSHT hydraulic motor is always cheated as one component and usually as a second-order transfer function when its input and output variables are flowrate of hydraulic oil and rotary speed of crankshaft, respectively. For the new type hydraulic motor, because of the changing states of HSVs, the model can be established by analysing each working cylinders in their working phase. Therefore, the mathematical model of the new type hydraulic motor includes two main parts. One is the model of high-speed solenoid on/off valve and the other is the dynamical model of working cylinder.

The return pressure of hydraulic motor and the supply pressure are both constants.
The temperature and bulk modulus of elasticity are considered to be constants.
The friction in each working cylinder is neglected.
The external and internal leakages of hydraulic motor are neglected.
The ten HSVs are considered to have the same flowrate characteristics.
The geometrical features of five cylinders of hydraulic motor are considered to be same.

sec.title: 4.1 Simulation results with no external torque
sec.p:
It is known from the model of HSV that the flowrate which passes through it alters with the duty cycle of control signal. Then, it can be inferred that the rotary speed of the hydraulic motor will also change according to different duty cycle. The results of speed adjusting with no external torque (TL = 0 ) are shown in Fig.4. In Fig. 4(a), the full line is the result with 100 per cent duty cycle; the dotted and the dashdot lines are the results of 80 per cent and 60 per cent duty cycle, respectively. In Fig. 4(b), the full line is the result with 50 per cent duty cycle; the dotted and the dashdot lines are the results of 40 per cent and 30 per cent duty cycle, respectively. From Fig. 4(a), it can be seen that the average rotary speed is about 89 r/min after 1 s when the duty cycle is 100 per cent; the average rotary speed reduces to 74 and 51 r/min when the duty cycle is 80 per cent and 60per cent. In Fig. 4(b), the average rotary speed is about 42, 33, and 23 r/min after 1 s. The rotary speed changes with the duty cycle of control signal of HSVs. The larger the duty cycle is, the faster the rotary speedis. Therefore, the speed adjusting of the new type hydraulic motor with digital distributor can be easily done by changing the duty cycle of control signal which applied to the HSVs. Fig. 4
Simulation results for speed adjusting characteristics with no external torque

It is also reflected in Fig. 4 that the rotary speed has ripple because of the numbers of working cylinders change between 2 and 3. For the duty cycle of 100 per cent, the ripple is about 2.3 r/min; the ripples are 2.2 r/min for the duty cycle of 80 per cent and 60 per cent. For the duty cycle of 50 per cent, 40 per cent, and 30 per cent, the ripples are 2.3, 2.4, and 1.9 r/min, respectively.

sec.title: 4.2 Simulation results with different external torques
sec.p:
The simulation results of speed adjusting with no external torque were given in Fig. 4. If the external torque is applied on the crankshaft, the speed adjusting characteristics will change. The results are shown in Fig. 5. In Fig. 5(a), it can be seen that the average rotary speed after 1 s reduces to about 75 r/min after 1 s when the duty cycle is 100 per cent; The average rotary speeds with other duty cycles are also smaller than the results reflected in Fig. 4(a). They are about 63, 43, 32, 26, and 19 r/min, respectively, after 1 s. Theaverage rotary speed is getting even smaller in Fig. 5(c) and (d) when the external torque is become larger (TL = 20 Nm). They are about 65, 52, 32, 25, 18, and 14 r/min. Fig. 5
Simulation results for speed adjusting characteristics with different external torque: (a) and (b) TL = 10 Nm; (c)and (d) TL = 20 Nm

From Figs 4 and 5, one can infer that the rotary speed changes both with the external load and duty cycle of control signal. The larger the external torque is, the smaller the rotary speed is; the larger the duty cycle is, the bigger the rotary speed is.

sec.title: 4.3 Simulation results of direction change
sec.p: As stated in Section 2, the new type of hydraulic motor can easily change the rotary direction by altering the distribution table from Tables 1 and 2. According to Tables 1 and 2, one knows the mathematical model for CW rotation will be very similar to the model for CCW rotation. For example, in the first angle section (0° ≤ φ < 36°), the working cylinders are (1), (2), and (3) for CCW rotation. While for CW rotation, the working cylinders are (1), (4), and (5) in the first angle section (324° ≤ φ < 360°). Therefore, in the control circuit, the working HSVs are 1, 7, 9, 4, and6. The mathematical model of the first angle section for CW rotation can be expressed as where p2 = p3 = pr .
Similarly, the mathematical model for the second angle section (288° ≤ φ < 324°) is where p3 = p4 = p2 = pr.

During the direction change situation, the distribution table alters between Tables 1 and 2. For the control circuit, the working HSVs change their states accordingly. The mathematical model also changes, the state variables in the model inhere the value from the last state. The simulation results for direction change situation are shown in Fig. 10.

In Fig. 10, the hydraulic motor rotates in CCW direction first and then it turns to CW rotation at about 3 s. The same method can be applied to the situation when the hydraulic motor changes its direction from CW to CCW.

sec.title: 5.1 Experimental setup
sec.p:
In order to validate the simulation results of the new hydraulic motor, the model machine is developed. The implementation of the new LSHT hydraulic motor is shown in Fig. 6. Fig. 6
Experimental setup of the new hydraulic motor

From Fig.6, one can see that the digital distributor is made up of ten HSVs, absolute rotary encoder, and other components. The pressurized oil flows into thedigital distributor. The absolute rotary encoder is connected to the rod which rotates with the crankshaft of hydraulic motor. The signal of the absolute rotary encoder is fed to ECU through the digital input channel. According to the distribution table, theECU decides which valves to be open, while the others remain closed. The pressurized oil then flow through the opened HSVs to the corresponding working cylinders. The oil in the other cylinders flow back to the tank from the HSVs.

sec.p:

In Fig. 8(a) and (b), the average rotary speeds reduce to 74, 60, 39, 30, 24, and 17 r/min when the external torque is 10 Nm. The average rotary speeds become even smaller when the external torque is 20 Nm. They are 63, 49, 29, 22, 18, and 12 r/min, respectively. Compared with Figs 4 and 5, the experimental results are conformed to the simulation results.

sec.title: 5.3 Experimental results of direction change
sec.p: From the simulation results, one knows that the rotary direction of the new type hydraulic motor can be easily changed by altering the distribution tables. This merit can be verified through the corresponding experiments, as shown in Fig. 10.
In Fig. 10, the simulation results are plotted with dotted line and the experimental results are with full line. One can see clearly from this figure that the rotary direction has been changed.

sec.title: 6 CONCLUSION
sec.p: This article focused on a new type of LSHT hydraulic motor with digital distribution and speed adjusting mechanism. The operating principle was introduced and the mathematical model established through analysis of working cylinders in hydraulic motor. The simulation was conducted and the results show that the new type of hydraulic motor could rotate continuously. In addition to that, the rotary speed of the new hydraulic motor could be changed easily by altering the duty cycle of control signal. In order to validate the simulation results, the model machine was developed and the experiments were carried out. The experimental results convinced that the new type of hydraulic motor could work well with the digital distribution and speed adjusting mechanism.
